text.content: Translation Principles

rich_text.plain_text: Translation Principles

text.content: The people in the Bible did not use modern measures such as meters, liters, and kilograms. Using the original measures can help readers know that the Bible really was written long ago in a time when people used those measures.

rich_text.plain_text: The people in the Bible did not use modern measures such as meters, liters, and kilograms. Using the original measures can help readers know that the Bible really was written long ago in a time when people used those measures.

text.content: Using modern measures can help readers understand the text more easily.

rich_text.plain_text: Using modern measures can help readers understand the text more easily.

text.content: Whatever measure you use, it would be good, if possible, to tell about the other kind of measure in the text or a footnote.

text.content: If you do not use the biblical measures, try not to give the readers the idea that the measurements are exact. For example, if you translate one gerah as “.57 grams,” readers might think that the measurement is exact. It would be better to say “half a gram.”

text.content: Sometimes it can be helpful to use the word “about” to show that a measurement is not exact. For example, 2 Samuel 21:16 says that Goliath’s spear weighed 300 shekels. Instead of translating this as “3300 grams” or “3.3 kilograms,” it can be translated as “about three and one half kilograms.”
